node.title: Is a Red Wave Coming for Biden’s Presidency?
node.description: The Republican Party has a lot of news to celebrate after last week’s elections. Why are voters cooling toward the Democratic Party?
node.content: ["This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.", "The Republican Party, you may have heard by now, has a lot of news to celebrate after last week\u2019s elections. In Virginia, a state that President Biden won by 10 points last year, it took back the governor\u2019s mansion, a feat it hadn\u2019t managed in over a decade. Republicans also came within striking distance of doing the same in New Jersey, a more deeply blue state that Biden won by about 16 points. And in New York, Democrats lost ground in local races too.", "What does the G.O.P.\u2019s rebound tell us about how the electorate is changing, and what does it portend for the country\u2019s political future in 2022 and beyond?", "In 1995, the political scientist Christopher Wlezien developed a theory known as the thermostatic model of American politics: The idea, as Vox\u2019s Zack Beauchamp explains, is \u201cto think of the electorate as a person adjusting their thermostat: When the political environment gets \u2018too hot\u2019 for their liking, they turn the thermostat down. When it gets \u2018too cold,\u2019 they turn it back up.\u201d", "In practice, the thermostatic nature of public opinion means that the president\u2019s party tends to struggle in off-year elections. Such swings have been observed for decades:", "The effect occurs for two reasons, The Washington Post\u2019s Perry Bacon Jr. explains. \u201cFirst, there is often a turnout gap that favors the party that doesn\u2019t control the White House,\u201d he writes. \u201cOff-year elections have much lower turnout than presidential ones, but typically more people from the party that doesn\u2019t control the presidency are motivated to vote in opposition to whatever the incumbent president is doing.\u201d A turnout gap was certainly in evidence last week.", "The second reason for thermostatic backlash is that some voters switch from the president\u2019s party, which also appears to have happened last week: Exit polls suggested that 5 percent of 2020 Biden voters backed Glenn Youngkin, the Republican candidate, while just 2 percent of those who voted for Donald Trump in 2020 supported Terry McAuliffe, the Democrat. \u201cThat only accounts for a few points,\u201d Bacon notes, but given that Youngkin won by less than two percentage points, \u201cthose small shifts matter.\u201d", "[\u201cHow shocking were New Jersey and Virginia, really?\u201d]", "As Democrats make sense of their losses, \u201cone fact stands out as one of the easiest explanations,\u201d The Times\u2019s Nate Cohn wrote. \u201cJoe Biden has lower approval ratings at this stage of his presidency than nearly any president in the era of modern polling.\u201d", "Why?", "There are strong counterarguments to both of these explanations. As Beauchamp writes, while Youngkin did at one point vow to ban what has disingenuously been called critical race theory in public schools, his campaign wasn\u2019t nearly as focused on the issue as some pundits made it out to be. Nor does the \u201ccritical race theory\u201d controversy explain the election results in New Jersey, where there was a similar backlash against Democrats despite the race\u2019s not being \u201cparticularly culture-war focused.\u201d", "The Times columnist Michelle Goldberg argues that the real reason education was such an incendiary issue this election cycle \u201clikely had less to do with critical race theory than with parent fury over the drawn-out nightmare of online school.\u201d Zachary D. Carter agrees: \u201cA lot of suburban parents lost faith in Virginia\u2019s public schools over the past year, and as a result, they\u2019re more open to conservative narratives about problems in public schools.\u201d", "As for the idea that the Democrats\u2019 underperformance owes to Biden\u2019s leftward shift on policy, one could just as easily \u2014 if not more easily \u2014 take the opposite reading of events: During his campaign, Biden openly aspired to a presidency that would rival or even eclipse that of F.D.R.; in office, however, his legislative agenda, which remains broadly popular, has been stripped down and delayed by his own party. Couldn\u2019t disappointment, not backlash, be to blame for his party\u2019s low turnout?", "Some say that last week\u2019s electoral shifts have even more general causes. Put simply, Americans are in a gloomy mood. A chief reason appears to be the pandemic, which has disrupted everyday life and the economy for longer than many expected.", "In the words of The Atlantic\u2019s Derek Thompson, Democrats are losing the \u201cvibe wars\u201d: \u201cDespite many positive economic trends, Americans are feeling rotten about the state of things \u2014 and, understandably, they\u2019re blaming the party in power.\u201d", "Republicans can succeed \u2014 and are perhaps even stronger \u2014 without Trump. As the G.O.P. pollster Kristen Soltis Anderson notes, Youngkin was able to enjoy the advantages of Trump \u2014 who over the past five years turned many formerly disengaged voters into habitual Republican voters \u2014 without incurring any of his liabilities. He did so mainly by neither embracing nor disavowing the former president.", "\u201cIn the current political environment, the Trump coalition seems primed to turn out and stick it to the Democrats even if Trump isn\u2019t on the ballot himself,\u201d she writes. And that means that \u201ctrying to use the fear of Trump to hold on to swing voters doesn\u2019t seem as viable a strategy for Democrats.\u201d", "Democrats\u2019 problem with white non-college-educated voters is getting worse. For decades now, left-wing parties around the world have been losing support among their traditional working-class base. The Democratic Party has also suffered from this phenomenon, as the white electorate has become less polarized by income and more polarized by educational attainment.", "That trend appeared to assert itself in Virginia\u2019s election last week, according to FiveThirtyEight, as the divide between white voters with and without a college degree grew.", "It\u2019s not just white voters. In recent years, Democrats have also lost ground among Latino voters and, to a smaller extent, Black and Asian American voters, with the sharpest drops among those who did not attend college.", "The writer and researcher Matthew Thomas argues that there are signs that the racial depolarization of the electorate may be accelerating: In New York\u2019s mayoral election last week, he notes, Queens precincts that are more than 75 percent Asian swung 14 points toward Republicans from four years ago, while Queens precincts that are over 75 percent Hispanic swung 30 points toward Republicans.", "\u201cThere\u2019s no easy solution to the decades-long demobilization of working-class voters,\u201d he writes. \u201cBut the left can\u2019t afford to chalk up all of our defeats to whitelash alone. This country is in the midst of a profound realignment along axes of culture and education that are about to make race and class seem like yesterday\u2019s news.\u201d", "[\u201cWhy Americans Don\u2019t Vote Their Class Anymore\u201d]", "As Bacon notes, the results from last week suggest that the Republican Party will suffer few electoral consequences in 2022 for its recent anti-democratic turn. \u201cIn normal circumstances, I\u2019d see that as a bad thing, since my policy views are closer to the Democrats,\u201d he writes. \u201cBut in our current abnormal circumstance, with U.S. democracy on the precipice because of the extremism of the current G.O.P., everyone needs to understand that normal could well be catastrophic.\u201d", "How should Democrats respond?", "In the end, as Moyn suggests, policy may not have the power to save Democrats from defeat. As The Times\u2019s David Leonhardt noted last week, some political scientists believe that Democrats overweight the electoral importance of policy and don\u2019t talk enough about values.", "And the values Biden ran on were, in effect, a liberal answer to Trump\u2019s \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d creed, a promise to restore \u201cthe soul of America\u201d to its former self. \u201cJoe Biden promised normality, Americans got abnormality, and Democrats got punished at the polls for it,\u201d Thompson writes in The Atlantic. \u201cThe path toward a more successful midterm election for Democrats in 2022 flows through the converse of this strategy. First, make things feel better. Then talk about it.\u201d", "Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at debatable@nytimes.com. Please note your name, age and location in your response, which may be included in the next newsletter.", "\u201cWhat Moves Swing Voters\u201d [The New York Times]", "\u201cWhy Virginia\u2019s And New Jersey\u2019s Elections Could Suggest A Red Wave In 2022\u201d [FiveThirtyEight]", "\u201cThe Powerful G.O.P. Strategy Democrats Must Counter if They Want to Win\u201d [The New York Times]", "\u201cBill Clinton Saved His Presidency. Here\u2019s How Biden Can, Too.\u201d [The New York Times]", "\u201cHow to Rebuild the Democratic Party\u201d [The New Republic]"]
